data.text:
Beware of this CD!

I just received the compilation called "The Heart And Soul Of Bert

Berns" released in October 2002 by Universal Records.

This is a compilation of tracks written and/or produced by the late

Bert Berns. He was a great song writer and a great producer who has

written songs recorded by the Beatles, the Rolling Stones and many

other famous artists.

This CD contains 10 original recordings from the 1960's.

The only information found on the inlay is that the CD was produced by

Doug Morris. No information about who did the mastering!

BUT:

This compilation runs for 28 minutes and 11 seconds and has a list

price of 14.98 dollars!!!!

Generally speaking the sound quality is acceptable for recordings made

in the 1960's, but one track "Baby Come On Home" by Hoagy Lands sounds

TERRIBLE. I own many CD compilations of 1960's recordings, but I have

never heard a single track with such bad sound quality. Apparently this

track is taken directly from a vinyl single or LP. It sounds as if they

just transferred this tune directly from an old scratchy single.

There is no information of the source of this recording on the

cover or the inlay except that this track is "under license from

Atlantic Recording Group".

If they couldn't find the original tape and they had to use a vinyl

record why didn't they inform about this and why didn't they use noise

reduction to get a "decent" sound? I have CD's with recordings

by Louis Armstrong made in 1928 that sounds better than this

track!

There is another track by Hoagy Lands "White Gardenia" which

also sounds as if it was taken directly from a vinyl record, but

this track don't sounds anywhere near as bad as "Baby Come On Home"

Christer

Stockholm

Sweden

A few interesting notes: As I understand it, Doug Morris, head of Universal Music (or whatever they are calling themselves this week) used to work with (or for) Bert Berns. He produced this as a tribute to a major talent.

Some tribute. As you say it is incredibly short, poorly mastered and not worthy of the man. I don't understand at all the point of doing a tribute to someone unless you put forth serious effort in doing so. Anyone who didn't know better would look at the track list and assume that Berns was a minor 60's writer-producer. They would be very wrong. He worked with and/or had his songs recorded by, amongst others, Garnet Mimms, Freddie Scott, Otis Redding, Otis Redding and Carla Thomas, Solomon Burke, Led Zeppelin, Janis Joplin, Ben E. King, Van Morrison, The McCoys, Them, The Drifters, The Strangeloves, Gene Pitney, The Kingsmen, The Jarmels, Erma Franklin, The Exciters, The Isley Brothers and, of course, The Beatles' incredible recording of "Twist and Shout."

If you like this music you can track down a 2-cd, 46 track collection called "Sloopy II Music Presents the songs of Bert Russel Berns" (put out by the publishing company that owns the songs - don't ask me where to buy it as living in the Los Angeles area I will very often find collections that are generally unavailable because of the proliferation of promos that are made available to people in the music business that find their way to the used record shops). You will find all of the artists above (except the Beatles) in a collection that is far more worthy of the man than the one put out by someone who is, arguably, the single most powerful record company executive around.

Utterly disgraceful. Doug Morris should have either not done this project or done it properly. He should be ashamed of himself.
